title: Mamhead Sensory Trail Walking Route

images.title: David Hawgood / Mamhead Point, view to the Exe and Dawlish
images.caption: Mamhead Point, view to the Exe and Dawlish. The viewpoint is by the obelisk in Mamhead Forest Park. Altitude 240 metres. The mouth of the Exe is due east.

images.title: Mamhead, obelisk by Jonathan Thacker, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Derek Harper / Stand of conifers near Mamhead Point
images.caption: Stand of conifers near Mamhead Point. Seen from the viewpoint across a clearing filling with bracken, the plantation descends the eastern slopes of Haldon.

images.caption: Picnic area near the car park, Haldon Forest Park

images.title: Roger Cornfoot / Path, to Colleywell Bottom
images.caption: Path, to Colleywell Bottom

images.title: David Smith / Mamhead Castle
images.caption: Mamhead Castle. This building housed the servants' quarters for Mamhead House. Despite appearances, it dates from the 1820s/30s. According to Pevsner's guide, it included a brewhouse, and beer was supplied by gravity to the house, which is to the east (and in the adjacent grid-square)

description: This circular walk follows the Mamhead Sensory Trail in Haldon Forest Park. The popular family trail runs for about 1.5 miles along a well maintained path.  You can start off at the free Mamhead car park where there's also a picnic area. On the walk you'll pass the photogenic Mamhead obelisk and enjoy some great views to Exmouth from the elevated position of the wood. Just to the east of the trail there's also the historic Mamhead House to see. It's Grade I listed and dates back to 1827.
